Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
An award has been made to The Franklin Institute to establish a Phase I Climate Change Education Partnership (CCEP), which will focus on assessing and developing effective climate change education strategies for urban audiences, in collaboration with The Center for Climate Systems Research, a unit of the Earth Institute, Columbia University, The University of Pittsburgh Center for Learning in Out of School Environments (UPCLOSE), the Carnegie Museum of Natural History, the New York Hall of Science, the Marian Koshland Science Museum of the National Academy of Science and the Association of Science and Technology Centers. The overall goal of the CCEP Phase I project is to establish a coordinated national network of regionally- or thematically-based partnerships devoted to increasing the adoption of effective, high quality educational programs and resources related to the science of climate change and its impacts.

Led by The Franklin Institute, the partners will create the Urban Climate Education Partnership (UCEP) project, which will establish local networks within four urban centers -- Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, Queens, NY, and Washington, DC -- forging links with informal and formal education partners, community groups, city government, and policy makers. Together this network will create and disseminate learner-focused climate education programs and resources for urban audiences. It is the vision of the UCEP to create an infrastructure of lasting collaborations to improve public understanding of and engagement with the science of climate change.

The audiences targeted by this project are those within the urban environments of the core network cities. This partnership's specific goals include: 1) identifying critical climate change adaptation and mitigation issues facing urban populations; 2) creating a set of Urban Learning Networks (ULN) each tasked with conducting inventories of new and existing educational resources for four specific target audiences (families, schools, communities, or adult/policy groups); 3) determining which critical climate issues resonate the most with their selected target audiences; 4) creating a plan for implementing programming created for each selected audience; 5) serving as a test bed for cross-platform implementation among network hubs, and 6) assessing the impact of cross platform climate change education.

The key deliverable of the UCEP Phase I project to develop a robust strategic plan for education, research, and evaluation activities for each city. Once implemented, the plan will increase climate science literacy for crucial urban audiences through the development of an integrated package of cross-platform climate education initiatives. Programs and curricula will be developed to be targeted (aimed at specific audiences), coordinated (presenting consistent and clear information about the science of climate change) and concentrated (delivered many times, through many programs).

More information on this project is available by contacting the PI, at ssnyder@fi.edu

Over the past two years The Franklin Institute and its partners, The Center for Climate Systems Research, a unit of the Earth Institute, Columbia University, the University of Pittsburgh Center for Learning in Out of School Environments (UPCLOSE), the Carnegie Museum of Natural History, New York Hall of Science, and the Marian Koshland Science Museum of the National Academy of Science have forged links with informal and formal education partners, community groups, city government, and policy makers, and  developed an interdisciplinary network to assess and meet the need to educate urban audiences about climate hazards and climate change. Together this network is positioned to create and disseminate learner-focused climate education programs and resources for urban audiences.

The UCEP Phase I objective was to develop a robust strategic plan for education, research, and evaluation activities for each city. Once implemented, the plan will increase climate science literacy for crucial urban audiences through the development of an integrated package of cross-platform climate education initiatives. Specifically the partnership has:

  1. Developed and refined a shared project vision to reach urban audiences with relevant climate change educational opportunities
  2. Established a strong core partner relationships and four city specific Urban Learning Networks (ULN’s) in Pittsburgh, New York, Washington, DC and Philadelphia
  3. Developed a strategic plan for the fulfillment of that vision
  4. Implemented two Pilot Programs to explore project approaches
  5. Created an inventory of relevant existing climate change education projects
  6. Evaluated the project, the partnership and its potential for future success

The project has developed an underlying approach focused on building networks of climate education and related organizations that could themselves be organized around shared goals, messages and language. These Urban Learning Networks will ‘tune’ their individual efforts to each other and strategically deploy a coordinated learning effort, one that produces resonance across the target audience. Reinforcing messages across multiple platforms will provide opportunities for coordinated interventions. Those interventions are then also concentrated, allowing members of the audience to encounter multiple reinforcing messages across several experience platforms. The approach further relies on connecting the audience’s personal passions (food, health, finance, etc.) to the urban systems that support them. It is these urban systems that are most directly at risk from a changing climate.

A targeted coordinated approach that relies on connecting personal passions to urban systems and how they will be impacted by a changing climate relies on engaging multiple climate focused organizations and efforts. These efforts need to be aligned and as such the audience will need to be defined by time, space and interest rather than any standard demographic qualities. The most appropriate target for the CUSP approach is a community. It is within the concept of a community that multiple existing programs can be brought to bear; the shared interests or values within a community provide the opportunity for shared passions; the interactions between individuals within communities provide the opportunity for message resonance.
